## Introduction
Workplace discrimination is a serious issue that affects many individuals in the United States. To address this problem, various federal and state laws have been enacted to protect employees from discrimination based on certain protected characteristics. This article will provide an overview of general law workplace discrimination laws, explaining the key legal concepts, application and enforcement of these laws, as well as highlighting notable legal cases.

## Overview of General Law Workplace Discrimination Laws
General law workplace discrimination laws encompass a range of federal and state statutes that prohibit discrimination in the workplace. The primary federal law that addresses workplace discrimination is Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. This law prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, and national origin. Additionally, other federal laws such as the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) provide protection against discrimination based on disability and age, respectively.

At the state level, many states have their own laws that provide additional protections against workplace discrimination. These laws may cover additional protected characteristics such as sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, and genetic information.

## Key Legal Concepts
To understand workplace discrimination laws, it is important to be familiar with key legal concepts such as disparate treatment and disparate impact. Disparate treatment refers to intentional discrimination against an individual based on a protected characteristic. This can include actions such as refusing to hire, demoting, or terminating an employee based on their protected characteristic.

On the other hand, disparate impact refers to practices or policies that may appear neutral but have a disproportionately negative impact on individuals with a particular protected characteristic. Even if there is no intentional discrimination, if a policy or practice has a disparate impact, it may still be considered discriminatory and in violation of the law.

## Application and Enforcement
Workplace discrimination laws are applied and enforced by various government agencies. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is the federal agency responsible for enforcing federal workplace discrimination laws. Individuals who believe they have been discriminated against must typically file a complaint with the EEOC before pursuing a lawsuit in court. The EEOC investigates complaints and may attempt to resolve them through mediation or conciliation. If a resolution cannot be reached, the EEOC may file a lawsuit on behalf of the individual or issue them a "right to sue" letter, allowing them to pursue legal action independently.

At the state level, agencies such as state human rights commissions or fair employment practices agencies may handle the enforcement of state workplace discrimination laws. These agencies have similar processes to the EEOC for investigating and resolving complaints.

## Notable Legal Cases
Several notable legal cases have shaped the interpretation and application of workplace discrimination laws. For example, in the landmark case of McDonnell Douglas Corp. v. Green, the Supreme Court established a framework for proving employment discrimination claims, known as the McDonnell Douglas test. This test requires the plaintiff to establish a prima facie case of discrimination, after which the burden shifts to the employer to provide a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for their actions.

Another significant case is Griggs v. Duke Power Co., where the Supreme Court held that employment practices that disproportionately exclude members of a protected group can be considered discriminatory, even if there was no intent to discriminate.

## Detailed Explanation
For a more comprehensive understanding of general law workplace discrimination laws, it is recommended to consult legal textbooks, case law, and legal professionals specializing in employment law. These resources can provide in-depth explanations of the legal principles, specific requirements, and recent developments in this area of law.

Remember, workplace discrimination laws are complex and can vary depending on the jurisdiction. It is always important to seek legal advice tailored to your specific situation if you believe you have been a victim of workplace discrimination.

By staying informed about workplace discrimination laws, individuals and entities can contribute to creating a fair and inclusive work environment for everyone.
